sp.speaker: Muge.
sp.p: Where's this lord fool here? 'slight you have made a pretty piece of service an't: raised up all the country in gold lace and feathers; and now with your long stay, there's no employment for them.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Good still.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'Slight I ever took thee to be a hammer of the right feather: but I durst have laid my life, no man could ever have crammed such a gudgeon as this down the throat of thee: to create thee a Christmas lord, and make thee laughter for the whole court: I am ashamed of myself that ever I choosed such a grossblock to whet my wits on.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Good wit i'faith.

I know all this is but a gullery now: but since you have presumed to go thus far with me, come what can come to the state, sink or swim, I'll be no more a father to it, nor the Duke; nor for the world wade one half step further in the action.

sp.speaker: Pac.
sp.p: But now your lordship is gone, what shall become of your followers?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Followers? let them follow the court as I have done: there let them raise their fortunes: if not, they know the way to the petty brokers, there let them shift and hang. Exit cum suit.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Here we may strike the plaudite to our play, my lord fool's gone: all our audience will forsake us.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Page, after, and call him again.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Let him go: I'll take up some other fool for the Duke to employ: every ordinary affords fools enough: and didst not see a pair of gallants sit not far hence like a couple of bough-pots to make the room smell?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Yes, they are gone: but what of them?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I'll press them to the court: or if need be, our muse is not so barren, but she is able to devise one trick or other to retire D'olive to court again.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Indeed thou toldst me how gloriously he apprehended the favour of a great lady ith' presence, whose heart (He said) stood a tiptoe in her eye to look at him.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: 'Tis well remembered.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: O, a love-letter from that lady would retrieve him as sure as death.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: It would of mine honour: we'll feign one from her instantly: page, fetch pen and ink here.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Now do you and your muse engender: my barren sconce shall prompt something.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Soft then: the lady Jeronime, who I said viewed him so in the presence, is the Venus that must enamour him: we'll go no further for that. But in what likeness must he come to the court to her now? As a lord he may not: in any other shape he will not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Then let him come in his own shape like a gull.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well, disguised he shall be: that shall be his mistress's direction: this shall be my Helicon: and from this quiver will I draw the shaft that shall wound him.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Come on: how wilt thou begin?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Faith thus: dear beloved.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Ware ho, that's profane.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Go to then: divine D'olive: I am sure that's not profane.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well, forward:

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: I see in the power of thy beauties.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Break of your period, and say, 'twas with a sigh.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Content: here's a full prick stands for a tear too.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: So, now take my brain.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Pour it on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I talk like a fool, but alas thou art wise and silent.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Excellent: and the more wise, the more silent.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: That's something common.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So should his mistress be.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: That's true indeed: who breaks way next?

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: That will I sir: but alas, why art not thou noble, that thou mightst match me in blood?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: I'll answer that for her.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: But thou art noble, though not by birth, yet by creation.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: That's not amiss: forth now: thy wit proves thee to be a lord, thy presence shows it: oh that word presence, has cost me dear.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well said, because she saw him ith' presence.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O do but say thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Soft, there's too many os

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Not a whit: o's but the next door to P. and his mistress may use her oh with with modesty: or if thou wilt, I'll stop it with another brackish tear.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: No, no, let it run on.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: O do but say thou lovest me, and yet do not neither, and yet do.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well said, let that last stand, let him do in any case: now say thus, do not appear at court.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: At least in my company.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: At lest before folks.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: For the flame will break forth.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Go on: thou dost well.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Where there is fire ith' hearth:

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: There will be smoke ith' chimney.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Forth.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Warm, but burn ▪ me not: there's reason in all things.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Well said, now do I vie it: come to my chamber betwixt two and three.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: A very good number.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: But walk not under my window: if thou dost, come disguised: in any case we are not thy tuft taffeta cloak: if thou dost, thou killest me.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Well said, now to the l'envoy.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: Thine, if I were worth ought; and yet such, as it skills not whose I am if I be thine; Jeronime: now for a fit pandar to transport it, and have at him.

lg.l: Come my good lord, now will I try my brain,
If it can forge another golden chain,
To draw the poor recluse, my honoured mistress
From her dark cell, and superstitious vow.
I oft have heard there is a kind of ●●●re
To fright a lingering fever from a man
By an imaginous fear, which may be true,
For one heat (All know) doth drive out another,
One passion doth expel another still,
And therefore I will use a feigned device
To kindle fury in her frozen breast,
That rage may fire out grief, and so restore her
To her most sociable self again.
Juno Lucina fer opem,
And ease my labouring house of such a care.
Mark but my midwifery: the day is now
Some three hours old, and now her night begins:
Stand close my lord, if she and her sad meany
Be towards sleep, or sleeping, I will wake them
With orderly alarms; page? Boy? sister?
All tongue-tied? all asleep? page? sister?
Alas Vandome, do not disturb their rest
For pity's sake, 'tis young night yet with them.
My lord, your only way to deal with women
And parrots, is to keep them waking still.
Page? who's above? are you all dead here?

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: 'Slight is hell broke loose? who's there?
sp.stage: He looks out with a light.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: A friend.

lg.l: Then know this castle is the house of woe,
Here harbour none but two distressed ladies
Condemned to darkness, and this is their jail,
And I the giant set to guard the same:
My name is Dildo.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Sirrah leave your roguery, and hearken to me: what page, I say.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Tempt not disasters: take thy life: be gone.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: An excellent villainy.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Sirrah? I have business of weight to impart to your lady.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: If your business be of weight, let it wait till the afternoon , for by that time my lady will be delivered of her first sleep: be gone, for fear of watery meteors.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Go to sir, leave your villainy, and dispatch this news to your lady.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Is your business from yourself, or from somebody besides?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: From nobody besides myself.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Very good; then I'll tell her, here's one besides himself has business to her from nobody .

sp.speaker: Vau.
sp.p: A perfect young hempstring.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Peace lest he over hear you.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: You are not the constable sir, are you?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Will you dispatch sir? you know me well enough, I am Vandome.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What's the matter? who's there? Brother Vandome.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Sister?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What tempest drives you hither at such an hour?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Why I hope you are not going to bed, I see you are not yet unready: if ever you will deserve my love, let it be now, by calling forth my mistress, I have news for her, that touch her nearly.

sp.speaker: Eur.
sp.p: What is't good brother?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: The worst of ills: would any tongue but mine had been the messenger.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that servant?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: O mistress come down with all speed possible, and leave that mournful cell of yours, I'll show you another place worthy of your mourning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Speak man, my heart is armed with a mourning habit of such proof, that there is none greater without it, to pierce it.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: If you please to come down, I'll impart what I know: if not, I'll leave you.

lg.l: Why stand you so at gaze sister? go down to him.
Stay bother, she comes to you.
'Twill take I doubt not, though her self be ice,
There's one with her all fire, and to her spirit
I must apply my counterfeit device:
Stand close my lord.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: I warrant you, proceed.

lg.l: Come silly mistress, where's your worthy lord?
I know you know not, but too well I know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Now heaven grant all be well.

lg.l: How can it be?
While you poor turtle sit and mourn at home,
Mewed in your cage, your mate he flies abroad,
Oh heavens who would have thought him such a man?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Why what man brother? I believe my speeches will prove true of him.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
To wrong such a beauty, to profane such virtue,
and to prove disloyal.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Disloyal? nay Nero gild him o'er with fine terms, brother, he is a filthy lord, and ever was, I did ever say so, I never knew any good ath' hair, I do but wonder how you made shift to love him, or what you saw in him to entertain but so much as a piece of a good thought on him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good sister forbear.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Tush sister, bid me not forbear: a woman may bear, and bear, and be never the better thought on neither: I would you had never seen the eyes of him, for I know he never loved you in's life.

lg.l: You wrong him sister, I am sure he loved me
As I loved him, and happy I had been
Had I then died, and shunned this hapless life.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Nay let him die, and all such as as he is, he lay a caterwauling not long since: oh if it had been the will of heaven, what a dear blessing had the world had in his riddance?

lg.l: But had the lecher none to single out
For object of his light lascivious blood,
But my poor cousin that attends the Duchess, lady Jeronime?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What, that blabber-lipped blouse?

lg.l: Nay no blouse, sister, though I must confess
She comes far short of your perfection.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Yes by my troth, if she were your cousin a thousand times, she's but a sallow freckled face piece when she is at the best.

lg.l: Yet spare my cousin, sister, for my sake,
She merits milder censure at your hands.
And ever held your worth in noblest terms.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Faith the gentlewoman is a sweet gentlewoman of herself, I must needs give her her due.

sp.speaker: Vand.

lg.l: But for my lord your husband, honoured mistress,
He made your beauties and your virtues too,
But foils to grace my cousins, had you seen
His amorous letters,

sp.p: But my cousin presently will tell you all, for she rejects his suit, yet I advised her to make a show she did not. But point to meet him when you might surprise him, and this is just the hour.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: God's my life sister, lose not this advantage, it will be a good trump to lay in his way upon any quarrel: come, you shall got 'sbody will you suffer him to disgrace you in this sort? dispraise your beauty? And I do not think too, but he has been as bold with your honour, which above all earthly things should be dearest to a woman.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Next to her beauty.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: True, next to her beauty: and I do not think sister, but he deviseth slanders against you, even in that high kind.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Infinite, infinite.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: And I believe I take part with her too: would I knew that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Make your account, your share's as deep as hers: when you see my cousin, she'll tell you all: we'll to her presently.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Has she told you, she would tell us?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Assure me, on her oath.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: 'Slight I would but know what he can say I pray you brother tell me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: To what end? 'twill but stir your patience.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: No I protest: when I know my carriage to be such, as no stain can obscure, his slanders shall never move me, yet would I fain know what he feigns.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.p: It fits not me to play the gossip's part w●●l to my cousin, she'll relate all.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: 'Slight what can she say? pray let's have a taste an't onward.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: What can he not say, who being drunk with lust, and surfeiting with desire of change, regards not what he says: and briefly I will tell you thus much now; let my melancholy lady (Says he) hold on this course till she waste herself, and consume my revenue in tapers, yet this is certain, that as long as she has that sister of hers at her elbow.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Me? why me? I bid defiance to his foul throat.

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.p: Hold there Vandome, now it begins to take.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: What can his yellow jealousy surmise against me? if you love me, let me hear it: I protest it shall not move me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Marry forsooth, you are the shooing horn, he says, to draw on, to draw on sister.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: The shooing horn with a vengeance? what's his meaning in that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Nay I have done, my cousin shall tell the rest: come shall we go?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Go? by heaven you bid me to a banquet: sister, resolve yourself, for you shall go; lose no more time, for you shall abroad on my life: his licorice chaps are walking by this time: but for heaven's sweet hope what means he by that shooing horn? As I live it shall not move me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Tell me but this, did you ever break betwixt my mistress and your sister here, and a certain lord ith' court?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: How? break?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Go to, you understand me: have not you a Petrarch in Italian?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Petrarch? yes, what of that?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Well, he says you can your good, you may be waiting woman to any dame in Europe: that Petrarch does good offices.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Marry hang him, good offices? 'sfoot how understands he that?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: As when any lady is in private courtship with this or that gallant, your Petrarch helps to entertain time: you understand his meaning?

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Sister if you resolve to go, so it is: for by heaven your stay shall be no bar to me, I'll go, that's infallible; it had been as good he had slandered the devil: shooing horn? O that I were a man for's sake.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: But to abuse your person and your beauty too: a grace wherein this part of the world is happy: but I shall offend too much.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Not me, it shall never move me.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: But to say, ye had a dull eye, a sharp nose (The visible marks of a shrew) a dry hand, which is a sign of a bad liver, as he said you were ▪ being towards a husband too: this was intolerable.

sp.speaker: Uaum.
sp.p: This strikes it up to the head.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p:
Indeed he said you dressed your head in a pretty strange
fashion▪ but you would dress your husband's head in a far stranger; meaning the count of saint Anne I think.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: God's precious, did he touch mine honour with him?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Faith nothing but that he wears black, and says 'tis his mistress colours: and yet he protests that in his eye your face shows well enough by candle light, for the count never saw it otherwise, unless 'twere under a mask, which indeed he says becomes you above all things.

lg.l: Come page, go along with me, I'll stay for nobody :
'Tis at your cousin's chamber, is it not?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Marry is it, there you shall find him at it.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: That's enough: let my sister go waste his revenue in tapers, 'twill be her own another day.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good sister, servant, if ever there were any love or respect to me in you both.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Sister? there is no love, nor respect, nor any conjuration, shall stay me: and yet by my part in heaven, I'll not be moved a whit with him: you may retire yourself to your old college, and there waste your eyes in tears, your heart in sighs, I'll away certain.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.p: But soft, let's agree first what course we shall take when we take him.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Marry even raise the streets on him, and bring him forth with a flock of boys about him, to hoot at him.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: No, that were too great a dishonour: I'll put him out on's pain presently.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Nay good sir spare his life, cut of the offending part, and save the count.

lg.l: Is there no remedy? must I break my vow?
Stay I'll abroad, though with another aim
Not to procure, but to prevent his shame.
Go page, march on, you know my cousin's chamber,
My company may wrong you, I will cross
The nearer way, and set the house afore you:
But sister see you be not moved for God's sake.
Not I by heaven: come sister, be not moved,
But if you spare him, may heaven ne'er spare you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: So now the solemn votary is revived.

lg.l: Pray heaven you have not gone a step too far,
And raised more sprites, than you can conjure down.

sp.speaker: Vand.

lg.l: No my lord, no, th'herculean labour's past,
The vow is broke, which was the end we sweat for,
The reconcilement will meet of itself:
Come let's to court, and watch the lady's chamber,
Where they are gone with hopeful spleen to see you.

sp.stage: Enter Roderique, Mugeron, D'olive in disguise towards the lady's chamber.

sp.speaker: Rhod.
sp.p: See Mugeron, our counterfeit letter hath taken: who's yonder think'st?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'Tis not Dolive:

lg.l: If't be not he, I am sure he's not far off:
Those be his trestles that support the motion.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: 'Tis he by heaven, wrapped in his careless cloak: see the Duke enters ▪ let him enjoy the benefit of the enchanted ring, and stand a while invisible: at our best opportunity we'll discover him to the Duke.
sp.stage: Enter Duke, Duchess, saint Anne, Vaumont, Uandome, to them Digue, whispering Vandome in the care, and speaks as on the other side.

sp.speaker: Dig.
sp.p: Monsieur Vandome, yonder's no lord to be found: my lady stays at hand and craves your speech.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Tell her she mistook the place, and conduct her hither: how will she look when she finds her expectation mocked now?

sp.speaker: Vaum.
sp.p: What's that, Vandome?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Your wife and sister are coming hither, hoping to take you and my cousin together.

sp.speaker: Uau.
sp.p: Alas, how shall we appease them, when they see themselves so deluded?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Let me alone, and stand you off my lord:

Madam, you're welcome to the court: do you see your lord
yonder? I have made him happy by training you forth: in a word, all I said was but a train to draw you from your vow: nay, there's no going back: come forward and keep your temper. Sister, cloud not you your forehead: yonder's a sun will clear your beauties I am sure. Now you see the shooing-horn is expounded: all was but a shooing-horn to draw you hither: now show yourselves women, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let him alone awhile Vandome: who's there? what whisper you?

lg.l: You've done? come forward:
See here my lord, my honourable mistress,
And her fair sister, whom your highness knows
Could never be importuned from their vows
By prayer, or th'earnest suits of any friends,
Now hearing false report that your fair Duchess
Was dangerously sick, to visit her
Did that which no friend else could win her to,
And broke her long kept vow with her repair.
Madam you do me an exceeding honour,
In showing this true kindness to my Duchess,
Which she with all her kindness will require.
Now my good lord, the motion you have made,To s. An.
With such kind importunity by yourself,
And seconded with all persuasions
On my poor part, for marriage of this lady,
Herself now comes to tell you she embraces,
And (With that promise made me) I present her.

sp.speaker: Eury.
sp.p: Sister, we must forgive him.

lg.l: Matchless lady,
Your beauties and your virtues have achieved
An action that I thought impossible,
For all the sweet attractions of your sex,
In your conditions, so to life resembling
The grace and fashion of my other wife:
You have revived her to my loving thoughts,
And all the honours I have done to her,
Shall be continued (With increase) to you.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Now let's discover our ambassador, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Do so.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: My lord? my lord ambassador?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: My lord fool, am I not?

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Go to, you are he: you cannot cloak your lordship from our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Come come: could Achilles hide himself under a woman's clothes? Greatness will shine through clouds of any disguise.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Who's that Roderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Monsieur D'olive, my lord, stolen hither disguised, with what mind we know not.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: Never strive to be gone sir: my lord, his habit expounds his heart: 'twere good he were searched.

sp.speaker: D'olive.
sp.p: Well rooks well, I'll be no longer a block to whet your dull wits on: my lord, my lord, you wrong not yourself only, but your whole state, to suffer such ulcers as these to gather head in your court ▪ never look to have any action sort to your honour, when you suffer such earwigs to creep into your ears thus.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's the matter Roderique?

sp.speaker: Rho.
sp.p: Alas my lord, only the lightness of his brain, because his hopes are lost.

sp.speaker: Mug.
sp.p: For our parts, we have been trusty and secret to him in the whole manage of his ambassage.

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Trusty? A plague on you both, there's as much trust in a common whore as in one of you ▪ and as for secrecy, there's no more in you then in a professed scrivener.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Why a scrivener, monsieur D'olive?

sp.speaker: D'ol.
sp.p: Marry sir a man cannot trust him with borrowing so much as poor forty shillings, but he will have it known to all men by these presents.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: That's true indeed, but you employed these gentlemen very safely.

sp.speaker: D'olive.
sp.p:
Employed? I marry sir, they were the men that first kindled this humour of employment in me: a pox of employment I say: it has cost me, but what it has cost me, it skills not: they have thrust upon me a crew of threadbare, unbuttoned fellows,
to be my followers: tailors, frippers, brokers, cashiered clerks, pettifoggers, and I know not who I: 'slight I think they have swept all the bowling allies ith' city for them: and a crew of these, raked like old rags out of dunghills by candle light, have they presented to me in very good fashion, to be gentlemen of my train, and sold them hope of raising their fortunes by me: a plague on that phrase, raising of fortunes, it has undone more men when ten dicing houses? Raise their fortunes with a vengeance? And a man will play the fool and be a lord, or be a fool and play the lord, he shall be sure to want no followers, so there be hope to raise their fortunes. A burning fever light on you, and all such followers. 'sfoot they say followers ▪ are but shadows, that follow their lords no longer than the sunshines on them: but I find it not so: the sun is set upon my employment, and yet I cannot shake off my shadows; my followers grow to my heels like kibes, I cannot stir out of doors for am. And your grace have any employment for followers, pray entertain my company: they'll spend their blood in your service, for they have little else to spend, you may soon raise their fortunes.

lg.l: Well monsieur D'olive, your forwardness
In this intended service, shall well know
What acceptation it hath won itself
In our kind thoughts: nor let this sudden change
Discourage the designments you have laid
For our states good: reserve yourself I pray,
Till fitter times: mean time will I secure you
From all your followers: follow us to court.
And good my lords, and you my honoured ladies,
Be all made happy in the worthy knowledge
Of this our worthy friend monsieur D'olive.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Good monsieur D'olive.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
